text:
How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has definitely had an impact on the dating process, but I cannot truly say that the impact has been negative.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has definitely had an impact on the dating process, but I cannot truly say that the impact has been negative.   I think that the impact has been positive because it has made dating more accessible to people who might not have had the opportunity to date in the past.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has definitely had an impact on the dating process, but I cannot truly say that the impact has been negative.   

In general, I think that the impact has been positive because it has made dating more accessible to people who might not have had the opportunity to date in the past.  In the past, meeting someone and starting to date them was mostly just a question of luck.  One had to be in the right place, at the right time, and had to be physically attractive enough to catch the eye of a passing stranger.  While people complain about the swipe-right culture of online dating, I don't think this is any worse (or really, any different) than meeting strangers in public used to be.

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

In my opinion, technology has definitely had an impact on the dating process, but I cannot truly say that the impact has been negative.   

In general, I think that the impact has been positive because it has made dating more accessible to people who might not have had the opportunity to date in the past.  In the past, meeting someone and starting to date them was mostly just a question of luck.  One had to be in the right place, at the right time, and had to be physically attractive enough to catch the eye of a passing stranger.  While people complain about the swipe-right culture of online dating, I don't think this is any worse (or really, any different) than meeting strangers in public used to be.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has definitely had an impact on the dating process, but I cannot truly say that the impact has been negative.   

In general, I think that the impact has been positive because it has made dating more accessible to people who might not have had the opportunity to date in the past.  In the past, meeting someone and starting to date them was mostly just a question of luck.  One had to be in the right place, at the right time, and had to be physically attractive enough to catch the eye of a passing stranger.  While people complain about the swipe-right culture of online dating, I don't think this is any worse (or really, any different) than meeting strangers in public used to be.  But now, more people can put themselves out there, and have many more opportunities to meet others.

Another big impact that technology has had on dating is that it has made it easier to find people who share your interests.  In online-dating apps, you can quickly and easily read a short paragraph about someone's interests, and even search for specific interests and filter out things that you are opposed to.  In the past, you might meet an attractive stranger, start dating, and eventually realize that you have little or nothing in common.  This could lead to painful breakups in the worst case, and to wasted time in the best case.  Technology has saved us from both outcomes.

In general, I think that the impact has been positive because it has made dating more accessible to people who might not have had the opportunity to date in the past.  In the past, meeting someone and starting to date them was mostly just a question of luck.  One had to be in the right place, at the right time, and had to be physically attractive enough to catch the eye of a passing stranger.  While people complain about the swipe-right culture of online dating, I don't think this is any worse (or really, any different) than meeting strangers in public used to be.  But now, more people can put themselves out there, and have many more opportunities to meet others.

Another big impact that technology has had on dating is that it has made it easier to find people who share your interests.  In online-dating apps, you can quickly and easily read a short paragraph about someone's interests, and even search for specific interests and filter out things that you are opposed to.  In the past, you might meet an attractive stranger, start dating, and eventually realize that you have little or nothing in common. How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has definitely had an impact on the dating process, but I cannot truly say that the impact has been negative.   

In general, I think that the impact has been positive because it has made dating more accessible to people who might not have had the opportunity to date in the past.  In the past, meeting someone and starting to date them was mostly just a question of luck.  One had to be in the right place, at the right time, and had to be physically attractive enough to catch the eye of a passing stranger.  While people complain about the swipe-right culture of online dating, I don't think this is any worse (or really, any different) than meeting strangers in public used to be.  But now, more people can put themselves out there, and have many more opportunities to meet others.

Another big impact that technology has had on dating is that it has made it easier to find people who share your interests.  In online-dating apps, you can quickly and easily read a short paragraph about someone's interests, and even search for specific interests and filter out things that you are opposed to.  In the past, you might meet an attractive stranger, start dating, and eventually realize that you have little or nothing in common.  This could lead to painful breakups in the worst case, and to wasted time in the best case.  Technology has saved us from both outcomes.  

In the same way, technology has also made it easier to find people who share your values.  People can reveal what they think is important right away, with a carefully written introduction.  It would be difficult to reveal these things to a stranger, or even to a blind date that a friend had tried to connect you with.  

While I think that online-dating has had the biggest impact, I can't ignore the impact that social media has had on the romantic scene.  However, I have to admit, that the impact it has had is not much different than that of online-dating.  One big advantage that social media has is that it helps us to discover people who are in our close network, but who we have simply not connected with yet.  This could be colleagues at work, or friends of friends at school.  There are many connections that might have slipped away in the offline world that can easily be made online.  

As for some other suggested topics such as texting and Netflix, I think that these are worthy of note, but not really game changers in their own right.  Texting is certainly an easier way to communicate than speaking over the phone, so maybe it helps potential romantic relationships to blossom.  It is another way to get an idea of someone's interests and values before you start dating them seriously.

What Do You Think About the Future of Dating?

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has definitely had an impact on the dating process, but I cannot truly say that the impact has been negative.   

In general, I think that the impact has been positive because it has made dating more accessible to people who might not have had the opportunity to date in the past.  In the past, meeting someone and starting to date them was mostly just a question of luck.  One had to be in the right place, at the right time, and had to be physically attractive enough to catch the eye of a passing stranger.  While people complain about the swipe-right culture of online dating, I don't think this is any worse (or really, any different) than meeting strangers in public used to be.  But now, more people can put themselves out there, and have many more opportunities to meet others.

Another big impact that technology has had on dating is that it has made it easier to find people who share your interests.  In online-dating apps, you can quickly and easily read a short paragraph about someone's interests, and even search for specific interests and filter out things that you are opposed to.  In the past, you might meet an attractive stranger, start dating, and eventually realize that you have little or nothing in common.  This could lead to painful breakups in the worst case, and to wasted time in the best case.  Technology has saved us from both outcomes.  

In the same way, technology has also made it easier to find people who share your values.  People can reveal what they think is important right away, with a carefully written introduction.  It would be difficult to reveal these things to a stranger, or even to a blind date that a friend had tried to connect you with.  

While I think that online-dating has had the biggest impact, I can't ignore the impact that social media has had on the romantic scene.  However, I have to admit, that the impact it has had is not much different than that of online-dating.  One big advantage that social media has is that it helps us to discover people who are in our close network, but who we have simply not connected with yet.  This could be colleagues at work, or friends of friends at school.  There are many connections that might have slipped away in the offline world that can easily be made online.  

As for some other suggested topics such as texting and Netflix, I think that these are worthy of note, but not really game changers in their own right.  Texting is certainly an easier way to communicate than speaking over the phone, so maybe it helps potential romantic relationships to blossom.  It is another way to get an idea of someone's interests and values before you start dating them seriously.

I was also specifically asked about Netflix, and I think that it is also noteworthy, but not game-changing.  The infamous "Netflix and Chill" date that people talk about is certainly a relic of a new tech-focused world, but is really not much more than a date that ends in "coffee" at one's apartment.  It was just a polite way to invite someone over for what you assume will be an intimate encounter.  Netflix has merely provided an opening that some people may mutually exploit.

In conclusion, I think that the future of dating will continue to be technology-focused, and I think that this is ultimately a good thing.  It will benefit a lot of people, and the one's who think that it is excessive, are probably the ones who had no trouble finding dates in the offline world.
